light: Bright to medium indirect light; avoid strong direct sun which can scorch leaves.
water: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil feel dry; keep soil lightly moist but never soggy.
humidity: Prefers moderate to high humidity (50–70%) but will tolerate average indoor humidity; very dry air may cause brown leaf tips.
temp: Best between 65–85°F (18–29°C); protect from drafts and cold below about 60°F (16°C).
soil: Loose, well‑draining aroid mix with peat or coco coir, bark and perlite for airflow around roots.
fertilizer: Feed at half strength every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer; little to no fertilizer in winter.
toxicity: Toxic if ingested (calcium oxalate); keep away from pets and children that chew plants.
tips: Many types are natural climbers – provide a moss pole or stake for larger leaves; trim leggy growth to keep plants full and rotate regularly for even light.

light: Asplenium
water: fern.jpg
humidity: Bright to medium indirect light; no direct sun which will scorch delicate fronds.
temp: Keep soil evenly moist but not waterlogged; never allow the root ball to dry out completely.
soil: High humidity (60–80%) is ideal; use pebble trays, grouping or a humidifier, and avoid dry drafty locations.
fertilizer: Prefer cooler to moderate temps around 60–75°F (16–24°C); avoid hot, dry air from heaters.
toxicity: Rich, moisture‑retentive mix with peat or coco coir plus some perlite for drainage.
tips: Feed lightly every 4–6 weeks during the growing season with a balanced, diluted fertilizer.
column13: Generally non‑toxic, but always confirm the specific species if pets are present.
column14: Mist lightly (avoiding some species that dislike wet fronds), remove brown fronds promptly and never let pots sit in standing water.

light: Low to bright indirect light; grows fastest in bright filtered light but tolerates lower light well.
water: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; overwatering is more dangerous than letting it dry slightly.
humidity: Average indoor humidity (40–60%) is usually fine; appreciate occasional misting in very dry homes.
temp: Thrives between 65–85°F (18–29°C); keep away from cold drafts and temperatures below about 60°F (16°C).
soil: Standard well‑draining potting mix with added perlite; avoid heavy, compacted soils.
fertilizer: Fertilize lightly every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer; withhold or reduce in winter or low light.
toxicity: Toxic if ingested (calcium oxalate); keep out of reach of pets and children.
tips: Excellent beginner plant; trim vines to control length and encourage branching, and propagate easily from stem cuttings in water or soil.

light: Bright indirect light is ideal; brief gentle morning sun is fine but avoid harsh midday or afternoon sun.
water: Water when the top 2 inches of soil are dry; allow excess to drain and do not leave the pot standing in water.
humidity: Prefers moderate to high humidity (50–70%); dry air can cause brown edges on leaves.
temp: Comfortable between 65–85°F (18–29°C); protect from cold drafts and temperatures below 55–60°F (13–16°C).
soil: Chunky aroid mix with bark, perlite and peat/coco for both moisture and good aeration.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in the growing season with a balanced or foliage fertilizer; reduce feeding in winter.
toxicity: Toxic if ingested due to calcium oxalate; sap may irritate skin in sensitive individuals.
tips: Provide a stake or moss pole so aerial roots can anchor; rotate regularly for even fenestration and wipe dust from leaves to keep them photosynthesizing well.

light: Low to medium indirect light for darker varieties; brighter indirect light for heavily variegated types, but avoid direct sun.
water: Allow the top 1–2 inches of soil to dry before watering again; slightly on the dry side is better than soggy soil.
humidity: Tolerates normal indoor humidity but prefers 50–70%; avoid placing directly near heating vents.
temp: Ideal range 65–80°F (18–27°C); avoid cold drafts and temperatures below about 60°F (16°C).
soil: Well‑draining all‑purpose potting mix with some perlite for aeration.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced houseplant fertilizer at half strength.
toxicity: Considered toxic if ingested; can cause mouth and stomach irritation.
tips: Great low‑light option; rotate for even growth and remove yellow or damaged leaves promptly to keep the plant looking full.

light: Very adaptable from low to bright indirect light; avoid prolonged strong direct sun which can scorch foliage.
water: Let soil dry out thoroughly between waterings; water deeply then drain, often every 2–4 weeks depending on conditions.
humidity: Does well in typical home humidity (30–50%) and does not require extra humidity.
temp: Handles a wide range of indoor temps, ideally 65–85°F (18–29°C); protect from cold below about 55–60°F (13–16°C).
soil: Very well‑draining mix such as regular potting soil heavily amended with perlite or cactus mix.
fertilizer: Light feeder; fertilize at half strength every 6–8 weeks during active growth if desired.
toxicity: Toxic if ingested and sap may irritate skin; keep away from pets and children.
tips: Extremely prone to root rot if overwatered; when in doubt, wait to water. Rotate occasionally to keep stems growing upright rather than leaning toward the light.

light: Bright to medium indirect light; avoid direct sun which can scorch and fade leaves; tolerates some lower light but growth slows.
water: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; keep evenly moist but never soggy.
humidity: Average indoor humidity is acceptable, though 50–70% helps prevent crispy edges on large leaves.
temp: Prefers 65–80°F (18–27°C); protect from chilly drafts and sudden temperature drops.
soil: Well‑draining peat‑based potting mix with added perlite or bark to avoid compaction.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer; no need to feed in winter.
toxicity: Highly toxic if ingested, causing severe mouth and throat irritation; sap can irritate skin and eyes – handle with care and keep away from pets and children.
tips: Rotate regularly for even growth; prune back leggy stems to encourage bushier plants and use gloves when handling to avoid sap contact.

light: Bright, indirect light is best; can tolerate medium light but avoid prolonged direct sun, especially through hot windows.
water: Water thoroughly when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; avoid letting it sit in water and reduce watering in winter.
humidity: Prefers moderate humidity (50–60%); will tolerate normal homes but appreciates occasional misting or a pebble tray.
temp: Best around 65–80°F (18–27°C); protect from cold drafts and sudden swings in temperature.
soil: Well‑draining potting mix with some sand or perlite; avoid heavy, compact soils.
fertilizer: Feed monthly in spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer at half strength; do not fertilize in winter when growth slows.
toxicity: Generally considered non‑toxic to pets and people.
tips: Rotate the plant for even growth, occasionally wipe dust from leaves and avoid overpotting which can lead to soggy soil around the roots.

light: Bright indirect light is ideal; can tolerate medium light but becomes leggy in low light; avoid harsh direct sun through glass.
water: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil have dried; allow excess water to drain freely and never leave the pot in a saucer of water.
humidity: Average indoor humidity is usually adequate; avoid extremely dry air and mist lightly if leaf edges brown.
temp: Thrives at 60–80°F (16–27°C); protect from cold drafts and temperatures below 55°F (13°C).
soil: Standard well‑draining potting mix with perlite; ensure the pot has good drainage.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer; taper off in fall and winter.
toxicity: Mildly toxic if ingested and can cause irritation; keep away from pets and children who chew plants.
tips: Pinch or prune tips to maintain a compact shape and encourage branching; rotate regularly so the plant grows upright instead of leaning.

light: Bright, indirect light; too little light reduces flowering, while direct sun can scorch leaves.
water: Keep soil lightly and evenly moist, watering when the top 1–2 inches feel just barely dry; never allow the root zone to completely dry out.
humidity: Prefers high humidity (60–80%); use a pebble tray, humidifier or grouping with other plants to raise humidity.
temp: Ideal temps of 65–80°F (18–27°C); avoid cold drafts and temperatures below about 60°F (16°C).
soil: Loose, chunky aroid mix with peat or coco, bark and perlite for excellent drainage and aeration.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in the growing season with a high‑phosphorus or balanced fertilizer at low strength to support blooms.
toxicity: Toxic if ingested; sap may irritate skin and mucous membranes.
tips: Remove spent blooms and yellowing leaves to keep the plant tidy; avoid letting water sit in the central crown to reduce rot risk.

light: Medium to bright indirect light; variegated and silver types need the brighter end to maintain pattern; avoid intense direct sun.
water: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; do not allow the plant to sit in water, and avoid letting the soil stay soggy for long periods.
humidity: Average home humidity is fine, though 50–70% keeps foliage lush and reduces crispy edges on thinner leaves.
temp: Best between 65–85°F (18–29°C); protect from cold drafts and temps below about 60°F (16°C).
soil: Well‑draining aroid mix or standard potting mix amended with perlite and bark for good aeration.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced houseplant fertilizer at half strength.
toxicity: Mildly toxic if ingested; keep away from pets and children that may chew on foliage.
tips: Great for hanging baskets or climbing; trim vines to keep plants full and propagate easily from stem cuttings to create fuller pots.

light: Bright, indirect light is ideal; tolerates medium light but may become leggy; avoid prolonged direct sun which can burn leaves.
water: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; allow excess water to drain and do not let the soil stay constantly wet.
humidity: Prefers moderate to high humidity (50–70%); dry air can cause brown tips or edges.
temp: Comfortable around 65–85°F (18–29°C); protect from temperatures below about 60°F (16°C).
soil: Chunky, well‑draining aroid mix rich in organic matter with bark and perlite.
fertilizer: Feed every 4 weeks during the growing season with a balanced fertilizer at half strength.
toxicity: Toxic if ingested; sap may irritate skin and eyes.
tips: Provide a moss pole or trellis for climbing, which encourages larger leaves and fenestrations; prune vines to control height and shape.

light: Bright, indirect light or filtered light from an east or north window; avoid direct midday sun which can scorch leaves.
water: Water when the top of the soil feels barely dry to the touch, ideally from the bottom to avoid wetting leaves; use room‑temperature water.
humidity: Prefer moderate to high humidity (50–70%) but dislike water sitting on leaves; avoid misting directly on foliage.
temp: Ideal temperatures are 65–80°F (18–27°C); keep away from cold drafts and temperature extremes.
soil: Light, airy, peat‑based mix designed for African violets or similar fine‑textured soilless mixes.
fertilizer: Feed regularly at low strength (every 2–4 weeks) with a fertilizer formulated for African violets, especially when blooming.
toxicity: Generally considered non‑toxic to pets and people.
tips: Remove spent flowers and damaged leaves, rotate for even growth, and keep leaves clean and dry to prevent spotting and rot.

light: Medium to bright indirect light; avoid strong direct sun which can scorch or fade foliage; some species tolerate lower light.
water: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; many Dracaena prefer to stay slightly on the drier side and dislike constantly wet soil.
humidity: Average indoor humidity is usually enough; avoid very dry air for thin‑leafed species.
temp: Best between 65–80°F (18–27°C); protect from drafts and cold below about 60°F (16°C).
soil: Well‑draining potting mix with added perlite; avoid heavy, compact soils.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer at half strength.
toxicity: Many species are toxic if ingested by pets; err on the side of caution.
tips: Dracaena are sensitive to fluoride and salts in tap water; use filtered or let water sit overnight, and flush the soil occasionally to remove buildup.

light: Low to bright indirect light; tolerates very low light but grows fastest in bright filtered light; some direct sun is usually fine.
water: Allow soil to dry almost completely between waterings; water deeply then drain, often every 2–4 weeks depending on conditions.
humidity: Handles low humidity perfectly well; no special humidity required.
temp: Thrives at typical indoor temps 60–85°F (16–29°C); protect from cold drafts and temperatures below about 50°F (10°C).
soil: Fast‑draining mix such as cactus/succulent soil or regular potting mix amended with extra perlite or sand.
fertilizer: Light feeder; fertilize once every 6–8 weeks during spring and summer; do not fertilize in winter.
toxicity: Considered mildly toxic if ingested; can cause stomach upset.
tips: Extremely tolerant of neglect; the most common cause of problems is overwatering, so err on the dry side and use pots with drainage holes.

light: Bright, indirect light; avoid intense direct afternoon sun indoors which can scorch leaves.
water: Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged, watering when the top 1 inch feels slightly dry; do not allow complete dry‑outs.
humidity: Prefers moderate to high humidity (50–70%); dry air can cause brown edges and leaf drop.
temp: Likes temperatures between 65–80°F (18–27°C); protect from drafts and cold below about 60°F (16°C).
soil: Rich, well‑draining potting mix with organic matter and some perlite for aeration.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks during the growing season with a balanced fertilizer; reduce feeding in winter.
toxicity: Considered toxic to pets due to caffeine in seeds and leaves.
tips: Prune lightly to maintain shape and encourage branching; avoid abrupt changes in light or watering which can cause leaf drop.

light: Bright to medium indirect light; avoid direct sun which quickly burns and fades patterned leaves.
water: Keep soil evenly moist but not soggy, watering when the top 0.5–1 inch is just barely dry; never let the root ball fully dry out.
humidity: High humidity (60–80%) is ideal; use a humidifier, pebble trays and grouping to maintain moisture in the air.
temp: Prefer warm temps of 65–80°F (18–27°C); very sensitive to cold drafts and temperature swings.
soil: Light, airy, moisture‑retentive mix with peat or coco plus perlite and a bit of bark for drainage.
fertilizer: Feed every 4 weeks in spring and summer with a diluted balanced fertilizer; avoid over‑fertilization which can damage sensitive roots.
toxicity: Generally non‑toxic to pets and people.
tips: Use filtered or distilled water if your tap water is hard, as Calatheas are sensitive to salts and chemicals; keep leaves clean and watch for curling or browning as early stress signs.

light: Medium to bright indirect light; avoid direct sun which can scorch patterned foliage.
water: Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged, watering when the top 0.5–1 inch is just starting to dry.
humidity: High humidity (60–80%) is preferred; dry air can cause curling or browning of leaf edges.
temp: Warm conditions of 65–80°F (18–27°C) are ideal; protect from cold drafts.
soil: Moisture‑retentive but well‑aerated mix similar to Calathea/Maranta (peat or coco with perlite and some bark).
fertilizer: Feed lightly every 4–6 weeks in the growing season with a diluted balanced fertilizer.
toxicity: Generally non‑toxic, but always verify for specific cultivars if pets are present.
tips: Part of the prayer plant family; leaves may fold at night. Provide stable conditions, avoid cold and use soft water for best results.

light: Bright indirect light; strong light keeps variegation vibrant but avoid direct sun which can scorch tips and edges.
water: Keep soil evenly moist, watering when the top 0.5–1 inch is beginning to dry; avoid letting the plant dry out completely.
humidity: High humidity (60–80%) is best; low humidity leads to crispy edges and leaf damage.
temp: Warm temps of 65–80°F (18–27°C) with no cold drafts or sudden changes.
soil: Rich, airy mix with peat or coco, perlite and some bark to hold moisture yet drain freely.
fertilizer: Feed every 4 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer at low strength.
toxicity: Generally considered non‑toxic.
tips: Very sensitive to water quality and dry air; use filtered water, boost humidity and keep away from heaters and cold windows.

light: Low to medium indirect light; avoid direct sun which scorches delicate leaves. Too little light causes leggy, sparse growth.
water: Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged; Fittonia wilts dramatically when dry but usually recovers if watered promptly.
humidity: Enjoys higher humidity (60–80%); terrariums or closed displays are ideal; avoid very dry air.
temp: Prefers 65–80°F (18–27°C); avoid cold drafts and chills.
soil: Rich, fine‑textured potting mix with good moisture retention and some perlite for drainage.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks during active growth with a balanced, diluted fertilizer.
toxicity: Generally non‑toxic to pets and people.
tips: Excellent for terrariums; avoid letting the plant dry out completely and pinch back stems to encourage a fuller mat of foliage.

light: Drosera and others
water: carn.jpg
humidity: Bright light to full sun for many species; Venus flytraps and many pitcher plants need several hours of direct light, while some tropical species prefer bright indirect light.
temp: Use only distilled, rain or reverse‑osmosis water; keep the growing medium consistently damp or sitting in a shallow tray of water, depending on species.
soil: Many prefer high humidity, especially tropical species and Nepenthes; North American bog species tolerate somewhat lower humidity if kept wet.
fertilizer: Most temperate species need cool winters and warm summers; tropical species prefer consistently warm conditions; avoid hot, stagnant air.
toxicity: Nutrient‑poor, acidic medium such as a mix of sphagnum peat and sand or perlite; never use regular potting soil or fertilizer‑enriched mixes.
tips: Do not fertilize the soil; plants get nutrients from insects. Over‑fertilizing or rich soils will kill carnivorous plants.
column13: Many carnivorous plants are non‑toxic but may be sensitive; always research the specific species if pets or children may handle them.
column14: Never feed meat or fertilizer; allow them to catch insects naturally or occasionally supplement with appropriate insect food; provide a winter dormancy for species that require it.

light: Bright, indirect light; an east window or shaded south window is ideal; direct midday sun can burn leaves.
water: Water thoroughly when the potting medium is almost dry but not bone dry; frequency varies by medium and environment (often 5–10 days).
humidity: Prefer moderate humidity (50–70%); use trays, grouping or a humidifier to boost humidity without keeping roots soggy.
temp: Generally like temps between 65–85°F (18–29°C), with a slight drop at night to encourage flowering; avoid cold drafts.
soil: Open, free‑draining orchid mix with bark, charcoal and perlite; roots need air, not dense soil.
fertilizer: Feed with a balanced orchid fertilizer at low strength every 2–4 weeks during active growth; reduce after flowering or in lower light.
toxicity: Most common Phalaenopsis and similar orchids are considered non‑toxic to pets and people.
tips: Do not let water sit in the crown of Phalaenopsis; provide bright light and small day/night temperature differences to encourage reblooming.

light: Bright, indirect light with some gentle morning or late‑day direct sun; many species bloom best with high light.
water: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; allow the potting mix to dry slightly more in winter; do not keep constantly soggy.
humidity: Average humidity is usually fine, but many species appreciate 50–70% for best growth and flowering.
temp: Prefer warm conditions of 65–85°F (18–29°C); avoid exposure below about 55°F (13°C).
soil: Very well‑draining mix with plenty of bark, perlite and a little peat or coco; similar to an airy orchid/aroid blend.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in the growing season with a balanced or bloom‑boosting fertilizer at half strength.
toxicity: Most Hoyas are considered non‑toxic and pet friendly, but always verify specific species.
tips: Avoid cutting off the flower spurs (peduncles) after blooms fade, as Hoyas rebloom from the same points; give them time and stable conditions to initiate buds.

light: Bright indirect light to some gentle direct sun; insufficient light leads to dull colors and leggy growth.
water: Keep soil evenly moist but not soggy, watering when the top inch is slightly dry; do not allow extended dry periods.
humidity: Prefers higher humidity (50–70%); dry air can cause browning at leaf tips and edges.
temp: Likes warm temps of 65–85°F (18–29°C); avoid cold drafts and temperatures below 60°F (16°C).
soil: Rich, well‑draining potting mix with organic matter and perlite; ensure good drainage.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer; reduce in cooler months.
toxicity: Some varieties may be mildly toxic to pets if ingested; check specific cultivars.
tips: Cordyline can be sensitive to fluoride and salts in tap water; use filtered or rainwater if possible, and trim off any brown leaf tips to keep the plant tidy.

light: Bright light to a few hours of direct sun indoors; flowering varieties need plenty of light to set buds.
water: Allow soil to dry out about halfway down the pot before watering; overwatering easily leads to root rot.
humidity: Average indoor humidity is fine; avoid misting heavily as fleshy leaves can be prone to rot if constantly wet.
temp: Prefer warm conditions of 60–80°F (16–27°C); protect from cold drafts and temps below about 50°F (10°C).
soil: Well‑draining cactus/succulent mix or potting soil with added perlite or sand.
fertilizer: Feed lightly every 4–6 weeks during active growth and blooming with a balanced or bloom‑boosting fertilizer.
toxicity: Many Kalanchoe species are considered toxic if ingested; keep away from pets and children.
tips: Deadhead spent flowers to encourage more blooms, provide bright light and reduce watering slightly after the heavy blooming period to let the plant rest.

light: Bright to medium indirect light; tolerates lower light but may produce fewer offsets; avoid very strong direct sun.
water: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil feel dry; keep slightly moist but not soggy, reducing watering in winter.
humidity: Average indoor humidity is usually fine, though they appreciate moderate humidity and occasional misting.
temp: Prefers temps of 60–80°F (16–27°C); avoid cold drafts and temperatures below about 50°F (10°C).
soil: Standard well‑draining potting mix with some perlite; avoid dense, heavy soils.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer; avoid overfertilizing which can cause brown tips.
toxicity: Generally non‑toxic to pets and people.
tips: Prune brown tips and remove old plantlets; repot when roots become crowded and enjoy the easy propagation from the hanging baby spiders.

light: Bright, indirect light with a little gentle direct sun; too little light results in few or no flowers.
water: Water when the top 1 inch of soil feels dry; keep evenly moist while actively growing and blooming, but never waterlog the soil.
humidity: Enjoys higher humidity (50–70%); dry air can cause leaf drop and fewer blooms.
temp: Warm temperatures of 65–80°F (18–27°C) are ideal; protect from cold drafts.
soil: Light, well‑draining potting mix with peat or coco and perlite; avoid heavy, water‑retentive soils.
fertilizer: Feed every 4 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced or bloom‑supporting fertilizer at half strength.
toxicity: Generally considered non‑toxic, though always verify specific cultivar if pets are present.
tips: Pinch stems to encourage bushiness, keep in a bright spot for best flowering and avoid sudden changes in light or watering that may cause bud drop.

light: Bright light to full sun for most desert species; many succulents prefer several hours of direct light, while some forest cacti prefer bright indirect light.
water: Water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings; in winter, water very sparingly.
humidity: Low to average humidity (30–50%) is usually ideal; avoid very humid, stagnant air for desert species.
temp: Most prefer warm conditions of 65–90°F (18–32°C); avoid exposure below 50°F (10°C) for many tender species.
soil: Very fast‑draining cactus/succulent mix with plenty of sand, perlite or grit; avoid regular potting soil alone.
fertilizer: Fertilize lightly during active growth (spring and summer) with a cactus or low‑nitrogen fertilizer every 4–8 weeks; do not feed in winter dormancy.
toxicity: Many species have spines or are mildly toxic; handle carefully and research specific species if pets or children are present.
tips: Use pots with drainage holes, provide maximum light you can indoors and avoid overpotting; when in doubt, water less rather than more.

light: Bright, indirect light for most indoor types; morning sun is usually fine but avoid hot afternoon sun on leaves.
water: Keep soil lightly moist, watering when the top 1 inch feels dry; allow slightly more drying between waterings for cane and succulent types.
humidity: Prefer moderate humidity (50–70%); very dry air can lead to crispy leaf margins, especially on Rex and fibrous types.
temp: Most do well between 60–80°F (16–27°C); avoid cold drafts and sudden chills below about 55°F (13°C).
soil: Light, well‑draining mix with peat or coco, perlite and a bit of bark; avoid heavy, waterlogged soils.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer at half strength; cut back in winter.
toxicity: Some species and hybrids may be mildly toxic if ingested; avoid allowing pets to chew leaves.
tips: Avoid wetting foliage repeatedly, especially on Rex begonias, to prevent spotting and mildew; deadhead spent blooms and remove faded leaves to keep plants tidy and reduce disease pressure.

light: Bright light with several hours of direct sun is ideal; will survive in bright indirect light but growth may be slower and more sparse.
water: Allow soil to dry at least halfway, preferably almost completely, between deep waterings; water less in winter.
humidity: Average indoor humidity is fine; does not require extra humidity.
temp: Prefers warm, bright rooms around 65–85°F (18–29°C); protect from cold drafts and temps below about 45–50°F (7–10°C).
soil: Very well‑draining gritty mix; use cactus/succulent soil or regular mix heavily amended with sand or perlite.
fertilizer: Fertilize lightly once a month in spring and summer; do not fertilize in winter.
toxicity: Generally considered mildly toxic if ingested; sharp leaf tips can cause minor injury.
tips: Use a heavy pot for tall plants to prevent tipping; rotate regularly so stems grow straight and avoid overwatering which leads to trunk rot.

light: Medium to bright indirect light; juvenile plants tolerate lower light but variegated or pink forms need brighter filtered light.
water: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; keep evenly moist during active growth but do not allow the pot to stay soggy.
humidity: Average to moderately high humidity (50–70%) is ideal; dry air may cause browning on edges.
temp: Thrives between 65–85°F (18–29°C); avoid temperatures below 60°F (16°C).
soil: Well‑draining potting mix with peat or coco and perlite; avoid compacted soils.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer at half strength.
toxicity: Toxic if ingested (aroid family); keep out of reach of pets and children.
tips: Young plants are bushy but become vine‑like with age; prune and root cuttings to maintain a fuller pot or train on a small trellis or pole.

light: Bright, indirect light; some species tolerate a bit of gentle morning sun but avoid harsh direct midday light, which can burn leaves.
water: Keep soil evenly moist but not waterlogged, watering when the top 1 inch is just beginning to dry; do not allow extended dry spells during active growth.
humidity: Prefer high humidity (60–80%); dry air can lead to brown edges and spider mite problems.
temp: Warm temperatures of 68–85°F (20–29°C) are ideal; many decline if kept below about 60°F (16°C) for long.
soil: Rich, airy mix with peat or coco, perlite and bark to hold moisture but drain well; pots should have good drainage.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks during the growing season; reduce or stop feeding during dormant or semi‑dormant periods.
toxicity: Toxic if ingested (calcium oxalate); keep away from pets and children.
tips: Many Alocasia rest or semi‑dormant in cooler or darker months; some leaf loss is normal then. Focus on stable warmth, humidity and careful watering to avoid rot.

light: F. benjamina and others
water: ficus.jpg
humidity: Bright, indirect light; some species tolerate a bit of direct morning sun but dislike harsh midday sun through glass.
temp: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; do not allow extended periods of soggy soil or complete dry‑outs.
soil: Average humidity is usually adequate, though 50–60% keeps foliage healthier and reduces leaf drop.
fertilizer: Prefer stable temps of 65–80°F (18–27°C); highly sensitive to sudden changes, drafts and cold below about 60°F (16°C).
toxicity: Well‑draining potting mix with some bark or perlite; avoid heavy, compacted soil.
tips: Feed every 4–6 weeks during active growth with a balanced fertilizer; reduce feeding in fall and winter.
column13: Sap can be irritating to skin; some species are toxic if ingested by pets—confirm specific types kept in pet homes.
column14: Ficus do not like change: avoid moving them frequently, and expect some leaf drop after big changes in light, watering pattern or location; prune carefully to shape once established.

light: Bright, indirect light; tolerates some gentle morning sun but avoid strong midday sun which can burn leaves.
water: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; do not let the plant sit in water or stay constantly soggy.
humidity: Average humidity is fine; appreciates moderate humidity but generally does well in typical indoor air.
temp: Comfortable around 60–80°F (16–27°C); avoid cold drafts and temps below about 50°F (10°C).
soil: Light, well‑draining potting mix with perlite; avoid dense heavy mixes.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer at half strength.
toxicity: Generally considered non‑toxic to pets and people.
tips: Rotate regularly to prevent leaning toward the light; remove and pot up offsets (“pups”) that appear around the base to create new plants or fill out the container.

light: Bright, indirect light is essential; too little light leads to lanky growth and few flowers, while direct sun can scorch leaves.
water: Keep soil evenly moist but never waterlogged; water when the top 1 inch is slightly dry and ensure good drainage.
humidity: Needs high humidity (60–80%) to thrive; low humidity quickly leads to browned edges and leaf drop.
temp: Prefers warm temperatures of 65–80°F (18–27°C); very sensitive to cold drafts and sudden temperature changes.
soil: Rich, moisture‑retentive but well‑draining mix with peat or coco, perlite and compost.
fertilizer: Feed every 2–4 weeks during active growth with a balanced fertilizer; reduce after flowering and in winter.
toxicity: Considered mildly toxic if ingested; sap may irritate skin.
tips: Often treated as a high‑maintenance flowering houseplant; best success comes from steady warmth, high humidity, bright light and very consistent watering.

light: Bright, indirect light; too little light causes muted colors and leggy vines, while direct sun can scorch leaves.
water: Keep soil lightly and consistently moist, watering when the top 0.5–1 inch feels slightly dry; avoid waterlogging.
humidity: Enjoys higher humidity (50–70%); dry air can cause crisping of leaf edges.
temp: Prefers warm temperatures around 65–80°F (18–27°C); avoid cold drafts and temps below about 60°F (16°C).
soil: Rich, well‑draining potting mix with peat or coco and perlite for aeration.
fertilizer: Feed every 4 weeks in the growing season with a balanced fertilizer at low strength.
toxicity: Generally considered non‑toxic, but always confirm for homes with pets that chew foliage.
tips: Provide a trellis or hanging basket for cascading vines; pinch tips to encourage branching and maintain a fuller plant.

scientific_name: Crassula ovata and other Crassula spp.
light: Bright light to full sun indoors; a few hours of direct sun through an east or south window helps maintain compact growth and red leaf edges on some cultivars.
water: Allow soil to dry out almost completely between thorough waterings; in winter, water very sparingly.
humidity: Low indoor humidity is fine; avoid overly humid, stagnant conditions.
temp: Prefer 60–80°F (16–27°C) during growth and cooler, very bright conditions in winter if possible (but generally above 45–50°F / 7–10°C).
soil: Fast‑draining cactus/succulent mix with plenty of mineral grit; avoid moisture‑holding peat‑heavy soils on their own.
fertilizer: Feed lightly once a month in spring and summer with a low‑nitrogen cactus or succulent fertilizer; do not feed in winter.
toxicity: Mildly toxic if ingested in quantity; may cause stomach upset in pets.
tips: Rotate regularly for even growth, avoid splashing water on leaves in strong sunlight to prevent spotting, and always prioritize underwatering over overwatering.

light: Bright, indirect light to light shade; can tolerate lower light but may become leggy; avoid strong direct sun which burns leaves.
water: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; keep evenly moist during active growth but reduce watering in winter.
humidity: Average to moderately high humidity is beneficial; very dry air can cause browning at leaf tips.
temp: Prefers 60–75°F (16–24°C); tolerates slightly cooler conditions but avoid frost indoors.
soil: Rich, well‑draining potting mix with organic matter and some perlite.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer.
toxicity: Considered mildly toxic if ingested; treat as potentially unsafe for pets that chew plants.
tips: Rotate the plant for even growth, prune lightly to maintain shape and avoid placing it in very hot, dry spots where foliage can scorch.

light: Neoregelia and others
water: brom.jpg
humidity: Bright, indirect light; some species tolerate gentle morning sun but most prefer filtered light indoors.
temp: Keep the central cup (for tank bromeliads) filled with fresh water and flush it periodically; keep potting mix lightly moist but not soggy.
soil: Prefer higher humidity (50–70%); dry air may cause browning at leaf tips.
fertilizer: Most house bromeliads like temps between 65–85°F (18–29°C); protect from cold below about 55°F (13°C).
toxicity: Very free‑draining orchid‑style mix, or a blend of bark, coco chips and a bit of peat; roots prefer air and should never sit in heavy soil.
tips: Feed very lightly with a diluted fertilizer, either in the cup or soil, every 4–6 weeks during active growth; avoid strong fertilizer which can burn leaves.
column13: Most commonly grown bromeliads are non‑toxic, but always confirm for homes with pets.
column14: After flowering, the mother plant slowly declines while producing pups around the base; allow pups to reach at least one‑third the size of the parent before separating and potting individually.

light: Medium to bright indirect light; tolerates lower light but variegated types need brighter filtered light.
water: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; keep soil lightly moist but not constantly soggy.
humidity: Enjoys moderate to high humidity (50–70%); dry air may cause brown tips.
temp: Prefers warm temps of 65–85°F (18–29°C); avoid cold drafts and sudden temperature changes.
soil: Rich, well‑draining aroid‑type mix with peat or coco, perlite and some bark.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in the growing season with a balanced fertilizer at half strength.
toxicity: Likely toxic if ingested (aroid family); keep away from pets and children.
tips: Often described as a “low‑light philodendron‑like” plant; provide stable conditions and avoid overwatering to keep foliage lush and glossy.

light: Medium indirect light; too much direct sun causes fading and scorch, while very low light reduces color and movement.
water: Keep soil evenly moist but not soaked, watering when the top 0.5–1 inch feels slightly dry; never allow the root ball to dry out completely.
humidity: High humidity (60–80%) is ideal; low humidity causes curling leaves and brown edges.
temp: Warm temps of 65–80°F (18–27°C); avoid cold drafts and rapid fluctuations.
soil: Rich, well‑draining mix with peat or coco, perlite and a bit of bark to hold moisture yet drain freely.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer with a diluted balanced fertilizer.
toxicity: Generally non‑toxic to pets and people.
tips: Part of the prayer plant family; leaves move up at night and down during the day. Use soft water, maintain humidity and trim leggy or damaged growth to keep plants full.

light: Bright, indirect light to some gentle direct sun; too little light results in weak growth and fewer responsive leaves.
water: Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged, watering when the top 0.5–1 inch is just beginning to dry.
humidity: Prefers moderate humidity (50–70%); very dry air can lead to browning and reduced vigor.
temp: Warm conditions of 65–85°F (18–29°C) are ideal; highly sensitive to cold drafts and chill.
soil: Light, well‑draining potting mix with peat or coco and plenty of perlite or sand.
fertilizer: Feed lightly every 4–6 weeks during active growth with a balanced fertilizer; do not over‑fertilize.
toxicity: Mildly toxic if ingested; handle carefully as stems can be somewhat spiny.
tips: Often grown as a novelty plant and not long‑lived indoors; avoid touching leaves constantly, as repeated stimulation can stress the plant and reduce overall health.

light: Bright, indirect light to a little gentle direct sun; too little light results in weak, floppy growth.
water: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; keep evenly moist while actively growing, but reduce watering when foliage dies back for dormancy.
humidity: Average indoor humidity is generally fine; does not usually require extra humidity.
temp: Prefers cool to moderate temps of 60–75°F (16–24°C); avoid hot, dry conditions.
soil: Well‑draining potting mix with some perlite; bulbs and tubers dislike sitting in soggy soil.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in active growth with a balanced fertilizer at low strength; stop during dormancy.
toxicity: Some Oxalis species can be mildly toxic if ingested in large quantities due to oxalic acid; supervise pets.
tips: Expect a natural rest period where foliage may yellow and die back; reduce water, keep pot in a cool, bright spot and resume normal care when new leaves appear.

light: pep.jpg
water: Medium to bright indirect light; many tolerate lower light but grow more compact and colorful in brighter filtered light.
humidity: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; succulent‑leafed types prefer to dry a bit more between waterings.
temp: Average indoor humidity is usually adequate; some fine‑leaved types appreciate slightly higher humidity.
soil: Prefer temps between 65–80°F (18–27°C); avoid cold drafts and temperatures below about 55°F (13°C).
fertilizer: Loose, well‑draining mix with peat or coco, perlite and some bark; many Peperomia resent heavy, wet soils.
toxicity: Feed every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer at half strength.
tips: Generally considered non‑toxic to pets and people.
column13: Small root systems mean they prefer smaller pots; avoid overpotting and overwatering, and pinch back stems to keep a compact habit.

light: Dypsis and other small palms
water: palm.jpg
humidity: Bright to medium indirect light; direct sun through glass can scorch fronds on many indoor species.
temp: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; most palms prefer evenly moist, never soggy, soil and will suffer if allowed to completely dry out repeatedly.
soil: Prefer moderate humidity (50–70%); very dry air can lead to brown leaf tips and edges.
fertilizer: Most indoor palms like temperatures of 65–80°F (18–27°C); avoid cold drafts and sudden temperature drops.
toxicity: Rich, well‑draining potting mix with some sand or perlite; palms dislike heavy, waterlogged soils.
tips: Feed every 4–6 weeks in the growing season with a palm or balanced fertilizer; under‑fertilizing is safer than overdoing it.
column13: Many palms are non‑toxic, but always check the specific species for pet safety and avoid confusing them with look‑alike toxic plants.
column14: Never remove browning tips by cutting into green tissue; instead, trim only the dead brown parts. Avoid heavy pruning of fronds and repot palms only when absolutely necessary.

light: Bright, indirect light; can tolerate medium light but may become leggy and prone to pests in low light.
water: Water when the top 1 inch of soil is dry; keep slightly moist but not soggy, and reduce watering a bit in winter.
humidity: Prefers moderate humidity; dry indoor air can encourage spider mites and browning edges.
temp: Cool to moderate temps of 55–75°F (13–24°C) are best; avoid hot, stagnant air and strong heat sources.
soil: Well‑draining potting mix with some perlite; avoid letting the root zone stay waterlogged.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer.
toxicity: Considered toxic if ingested; keep away from pets and children.
tips: Provide good air circulation and inspect frequently for spider mites; cooler, brighter conditions give the best foliage quality indoors.

light: trad.jpg
water: Bright, indirect light to a little gentle direct sun; insufficient light leads to green, stretched vines with faded stripes.
humidity: Water when the top 1 inch of soil is dry; keep evenly moist but not soggy, especially in brighter light.
temp: Average indoor humidity is generally adequate, though higher humidity keeps foliage fresher and reduces crispy tips.
soil: Comfortable between 60–80°F (16–27°C); avoid cold drafts and temperatures below about 50°F (10°C).
fertilizer: Well‑draining potting mix with perlite; avoid heavy, constant wet conditions which can cause root rot.
toxicity: Feed every 4 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer at low strength.
tips: Mildly toxic to pets; sap can be irritating, and foliage may cause stomach upset if eaten.
column13: Pinch or trim vines regularly to keep plants bushy and to remove bare, woody sections; easily propagated from cuttings to refresh older pots.

light: Bright, indirect light; too little light causes sparse growth and leaf drop, while strong direct sun can scorch leaves.
water: Keep soil evenly moist, watering when the top 1–2 inches feel slightly dry; avoid waterlogging and never allow completely dry‑outs.
humidity: Prefer moderate to high humidity (50–70%); dry air often leads to leaf drop and poor performance.
temp: Warm, stable temperatures of 65–80°F (18–27°C) are ideal; very sensitive to cold drafts and chills.
soil: Rich, well‑draining potting mix with peat or coco, perlite and compost.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in the growing season with a balanced fertilizer at half strength.
toxicity: Mildly toxic if ingested; treat with caution in pet households.
tips: Aralia dislike being moved or repotted frequently; choose a bright, draft‑free location and maintain consistent care to minimize leaf drop.

light: Low to medium indirect light; avoid direct sun which can scorch the foliage, and very dark corners which weaken growth.
water: If grown in water, keep roots covered with fresh, chlorine‑free water and change it regularly; if grown in soil, water when the top 1 inch is dry and keep gently moist.
humidity: Average indoor humidity is typically adequate.
temp: Prefers temps between 65–85°F (18–29°C); protect from cold drafts and temperatures below about 55°F (13°C).
soil: If grown in soil, use a light, well‑draining potting mix; if grown in water, use clean pebbles for support and maintain water quality.
fertilizer: Feed very lightly a few times a year with a highly diluted liquid fertilizer; overfertilizing is a common cause of yellowing.
toxicity: Toxic if ingested by pets (Dracaena genus); keep out of reach of animals that chew foliage.
tips: Use distilled or filtered water—especially in vases—to avoid salt and chlorine buildup; trim yellow stems and rearrange stalks as desired for decorative displays.

light: Bright, indirect light; tolerates some gentle direct morning sun but dislikes hot afternoon sun and very low light.
water: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; keep evenly moist but never waterlogged, and do not allow complete dry‑outs.
humidity: Appreciates moderate humidity (50–60%); very dry indoor air, especially in winter, causes browning at branch tips.
temp: Prefers cooler to moderate temps of 60–75°F (16–24°C); avoid hot, dry rooms and cold drafts.
soil: Well‑draining, slightly acidic potting mix with peat or coco and perlite.
fertilizer: Feed lightly every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer; avoid heavy feeding which can cause weak growth.
toxicity: Generally considered non‑toxic to pets, but always supervise plants around animals.
tips: Rotate regularly so branches develop evenly on all sides, and avoid heavy pruning—only remove dead or brown branches close to the trunk.

light: Bright, indirect light to some gentle direct morning sun; avoid harsh midday sun behind glass.
water: Soak plants in room‑temperature water for 15–30 minutes every 1–2 weeks (more often in dry, hot conditions), then shake off excess water and allow to dry completely within a few hours.
humidity: Prefer high humidity but adapt well if given regular soakings and good air movement.
temp: Happy in a wide range of household temps, generally 60–85°F (16–29°C); avoid cold drafts and freezing temperatures.
soil: No soil required; can be mounted on wood, shells or other decor as long as water can drain away and leaves dry quickly.
fertilizer: Feed with a very dilute bromeliad or orchid fertilizer in the soaking water once a month during active growth.
toxicity: Generally considered non‑toxic to pets.
tips: Ensure plants dry fully after watering to prevent rot; provide good air circulation and avoid placing them in enclosed, stagnant containers without ventilation.

light: Bright, indirect light to several hours of direct sun; indoors they often perform best near a very bright south or west window.
water: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; water deeply and allow excess to drain; slightly drier in winter.
humidity: Average to moderately high humidity is ideal; very dry air may cause brown tips.
temp: Prefer warmth, ideally 65–85°F (18–29°C); protect from cold drafts and temperatures below about 55°F (13°C).
soil: Rich, well‑draining potting mix with compost and perlite; avoid heavy, soggy soils.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks during the growing season with a balanced or bloom‑supporting fertilizer; reduce in winter.
toxicity: Generally considered non‑toxic to people, but some parts can be mildly toxic to pets if ingested.
tips: Bird of paradise need time and bright light to bloom indoors; allow plants to become slightly root‑bound before repotting and provide as much light as possible.

light: Bright, indirect light; avoid direct sun which easily scorches soft leaves.
water: Keep soil evenly moist but not soggy, watering when the surface feels slightly dry; do not allow long dry‑outs during active growth.
humidity: Enjoys high humidity (60–80%); dry air causes brown, crispy edges and poor growth.
temp: Warm temps of 65–80°F (18–27°C); avoid cold drafts and temperatures below about 60°F (16°C).
soil: Light, airy, peat‑based mix similar to African violet soil with added perlite for drainage.
fertilizer: Feed lightly every 4 weeks during the growing season with a balanced fertilizer at low strength.
toxicity: Generally considered non‑toxic, but confirm for specific hybrids if pets may chew leaves.
tips: Excellent for hanging baskets or as a trailing plant; avoid water on leaves in strong light and pinch stems to encourage branching and a fuller appearance.

light: heli.jpg
water: Very bright light with some direct sun; indoors, a sunroom or very bright window is usually required.
humidity: Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged, watering when the top 1 inch is slightly dry; do not allow the root zone to dry completely.
temp: Prefers high humidity (60–80%); low humidity leads to browning leaf edges and poor flowering.
soil: Warm tropical temperatures of 70–90°F (21–32°C); very sensitive to cold and drafts.
fertilizer: Rich, fertile, well‑draining mix with plenty of organic matter and some sand or perlite.
toxicity: Feed regularly in the growing season (every 3–4 weeks) with a balanced or bloom‑supporting fertilizer.
tips: May be mildly toxic if ingested; treat as potentially unsafe for pets.
column13: Best suited to very bright, warm indoor spaces or greenhouses; provide ample room, high humidity and strong light if you want to see flowers.

light: Bright, indirect light to some gentle direct sun; insufficient light leads to weak growth and few flowers.
water: Water when the top 1–2 inches of soil are dry; keep evenly moist during active growth but avoid soggy conditions.
humidity: Prefers moderate humidity (50–70%); very dry air can cause buds to drop and leaves to yellow.
temp: Ideal temps of 65–80°F (18–27°C); avoid cold drafts and temperatures below about 55°F (13°C).
soil: Rich, well‑draining mix with peat or coco, perlite and some compost; ensure good drainage.
fertilizer: Feed every 4 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer or one slightly higher in phosphorus to encourage blooming.
toxicity: May be mildly toxic if ingested; supervise around pets and children.
tips: Provide a trellis or hoop for climbing vines, avoid moving the plant when it has buds, and keep conditions stable to reduce bud drop.

light: Bright, indirect light; avoid hot direct sun through glass and very low light which leads to leaf drop.
water: Water when the top 1 inch of soil feels dry; water thoroughly and allow excess to drain, never leaving the pot standing in water.
humidity: Average indoor humidity is usually fine; avoid placing directly near heating vents which dry the air.
temp: Best in temperatures of 65–75°F (18–24°C); keep away from cold windows, drafts and temperature extremes.
soil: Well‑draining potting mix; many store‑bought plants already come in suitable soil—just be sure the decorative sleeve allows drainage.
fertilizer: Feed lightly every 4–6 weeks after the main holiday display period if you plan to keep the plant long term; little fertilizer is needed during peak bract color.
toxicity: Sap can cause mild skin irritation; leaves and bracts are considered only mildly toxic if ingested but may cause stomach upset.
tips: To keep plants colorful through the holidays, provide bright light, avoid cold and overwatering, and remove foil or decorative sleeves when watering so excess water can drain freely. Re‑blooming the following year requires strict dark‑period treatment beginning in early fall.

light: Bright light with several hours of direct sun preferred; tolerates bright indirect but grows slowly.
water: Allow soil to dry out completely before watering; water deeply but very infrequently.
humidity: Average indoor humidity is fine; very tolerant of dry air.
temp: Ideal 65–85°F (18–29°C); avoid cold temperatures below 50°F (10°C).
soil: Very fast‑draining cactus/succulent mix; avoid heavy moisture-retentive soils.
fertilizer: Feed lightly once a month in spring/summer; none in winter.
toxicity: Non‑toxic to pets.
tips: This is NOT a palm and behaves like a succulent—overwatering is the #1 killer.

light: Bright indirect light for best color; low light causes fading and stretching.
water: Keep soil evenly moist, watering when top 1 inch begins to dry; do not let completely dry out.
humidity: Average humidity is fine but appreciates >50%.
soil: Rich, well‑draining all‑purpose potting mix.
fertilizer: Feed every 4 weeks during active growth.
toxicity: Generally non‑toxic.
tips: Pinch frequently to prevent legginess and encourage a compact, bushy form.

light: Bright, indirect light; direct sun may scorch but too little light fades colors.
water: Water when top inch is dry; keep evenly moist but not soggy.
humidity: Average humidity acceptable.
soil: Rich, well‑draining mix.
fertilizer: Feed every 2–4 weeks during growing season.
toxicity: Generally non‑toxic.
tips: Pinch often to keep bushy and prevent flowering, which can shorten lifespan.
